answers.answer: Metformin does have some fairly common side effects, mostly gastrointestinal. For some people these do subside as their bodies adjust. However, you are on a relatively low dosage so if these don't subside soon I'd see your doctor and perhaps he will switch you to something else. But I'm wondering also if some of the effects you are experiencing are caused by blood sugar fluctuations, especially feeling confused and weak and shakey. I would suggest you test your blood sugar when you have these feelings and see if it is out of range

To lessen your tummy problem take your dose with food like with your mid-day meal. If it does help but your tummy still feels a bit upset try splitting the tablet in two parts and take at different times, again with food. And do not consume alcohol right after taking.

Carol,Your body had become accustomed to the high blood sugar levels.  When you first begin taking metformin, your blood glucose will begin to lower below what your accustomed to.  Your body may be reacting as if you have low blood sugar symptoms.  If this is the case, you will begin feeling much better in a few days.

Side effects from Metformin are very common but rarely long lasting. Generally your body should adjust within a week or two and your tummy troubles should subside. There are several different medications available so you should discuss your symptoms with your doctor. You are not stuck with just one choice. Your doctor should have given you a test kit so that you can check your blood sugar. Monitor it regularly, as directed by your doctor or diabetes consultant. The best help you can give your body is to try to maintain a healthy weight and watch your diet carefully. Hang in there!
